posts.name: Murilo Miranda Santos

posts.name: Murilo Miranda Santos
posts.cooked: actualy, we don’t use software for this. We want create a organization for our eletric by plan, organization, buy thing, space for use and another thing

posts.name: Roxxy S

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
Or are you trying to figure out how to lay out the electrical in the robot?

(Also, don’t be afraid to use Google Translate or similar, or post in Portuguese and we can use the same tools.)

Ou você está tentando descobrir como fazer a instalação elétrica do robô?

(Além disso, não tenha medo de usar o Google Tradutor ou similar, ou postar em português, pois podemos usar as mesmas ferramentas.)

posts.name: Murilo Miranda Santos
posts.cooked: No, I want software that helps me assemble my electrical system digitally to help me when I assemble it physically. That helps me with how much space I’m going to use, how many wires I’m going to use, how many components I’m going to use, where I’m going to position them, where and among other things.

posts.name: Roxxy S
posts.cooked: Many vendors include CAD models of components in the form of .step files that can be downloaded from the product page and imported into the robot CAD

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
First strategy on that: your team’s CAD software. You should have models for most or all of the electrical components, and those models ideally will include the terminals and/or built-in wires. Once you know what the design team is using in terms of motors, you’ll be able to start positioning motor controllers, the battery, the PDP / PDH , and the rest of the electronics inside the robot. For this, it also helps to ask the design team what areas of the robot electronics cannot be in. You’ll then use those locations to start mapping out the wire runs you need.

The next step would be to use a CAD software that specifically models electrical systems to build the wiring diagram. This may be a little bit more challenging, and may not reflect the robot’s physical layout. This is why you need both the regular CAD and the electrical CAD. Some CAD programs can do electrical in the main CAD program, but I’ve personally not had success in doing that so I can’t speak to how useful that will be for you.

NOTE: You don’t need to model every single wire. But it may be a good idea to figure out the cross-section area of each wire in a bundle to know how much volume you’ll need.

Primeira estratégia: o software CAD da sua equipe. Você deve ter modelos para a maioria ou todos os componentes elétricos, e esses modelos, idealmente, incluirão os terminais e/ou fios embutidos. Depois de saber o que a equipe de projeto está usando em termos de motores, você poderá começar a posicionar os controladores do motor, a bateria, o PDP / PDH e o restante da eletrônica dentro do robô. Para isso, também ajuda perguntar à equipe de projeto quais áreas da eletrônica do robô não podem ser incluídas. Você então usará esses locais para começar a mapear os fios necessários.

O próximo passo seria usar um software CAD que modele especificamente os sistemas elétricos para construir o diagrama de fiação. Isso pode ser um pouco mais desafiador e pode não refletir o layout físico do robô. É por isso que você precisa tanto do CAD comum quanto do CAD elétrico. Alguns programas CAD podem executar a parte elétrica no programa CAD principal, mas eu pessoalmente não tive sucesso nisso, então não posso dizer o quão útil isso será para você.

OBSERVAÇÃO: Você não precisa modelar cada fio individualmente. Mas pode ser uma boa ideia calcular a área da seção transversal de cada fio em um feixe para saber quanto volume você precisará.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
My team is working towards what @EricH described.

This year, the members of the electrical group participated in the initial detailed design of the robot to define where the panels holding the control system parts would go. They took into account what components were needed, suitable locations for those components and where wires could be routed to those components. These panels were then locked and approval from the electrical group was required to make changes to them.

We had members of the electrical group get trained in OnShape. They did the detailed design work to place the components on the panels and sub-panels. They also added mounting holes for the components and holes for strain-relieving the wiring. Space for wire routing channels was included when laying out the components. Attention was paid to which side wires and cables would enter the various components.

Some components were installed on sub-panels so most of the assembly and wiring work could be done outside of the robot. In some cases, Anderson connectors were pre-installed on the wires running to/from the sub-panels. The sub-panels were installed once the support structure was completed and the wiring to/from the sub-panels connected to other components and sub-panels.

We did not make a wiring diagram in past seasons, using the FRC wiring diagrams as a guide. We are currently working on figuring out how to make wiring diagrams to aid in the design and construction of the robot. They should also be useful for troubleshooting.

For planning the wire routing, we used the 3D CAD of the robot, with the control system components placed in it. We took screenshots from different angles using the Windows Snipping tool and drew in the various wire paths. We used different colors for the power wires, the signal and CAN wires, and the ethernet cables. While this was kind of crude, it was quick and easy to try multiple iterations to optimize the routing. The iteration was important since, in some instances, we moved components to make the wire routing shorter or easier and changed some sub-panels to add space to secure the wire bundles.  We then posted the pictures of the chosen wire routings to discord so that the people installing the wiring knew what to do. We are likely to continue with this method for planning the wire routing since it is so quick and effective.

We used a Brother label maker with 18mm wide tape to make labels for the wires. We started with a spreadsheet of all the wire connections. One of our team members figured out how to format the labels so that the text was printed across the 18mm width of the tape, and so that it repeated. Thus the labels could be just wrapped around the wire pairs and could always be read. He also figured out how to print the labels by using a Brother interface program, with the label maker connected to the laptop via a USB cable, saving a lot of tedious work. We made enough labels that each wire pair/group had labels along it’s whole length. Each function was given a unique name and the labels with the same name were used from the PDH end to the motor connections. Identical labels were applied on either side of the Anderson connectors connecting to the motor controllers. This made troubleshooting much easier and minimized the need to tug on wires in a bundle to figure out where they go.
